ALUMNI REUNION WELL PLANNED

The Johns Hopkins memorial
reunion, the greatest and most appropriate one of its kind that has
ever been attempted at this University, will be chock full of interesting features, the details of
which were worked out at the last
weekly meeting of the general
committee.
The reunion will be formally
opened on Thursday, June 19,
which will be the day for the reception of the alumni. The senior
dance will probably be held on
that night.
On Friday, a baseball game will
be played between the Johns Hopkins team and a visiting team,
most likely that of St. John's.
The memorial exercises will be
held on Saturday. Prominent
Hopkins alumni, such as President Wilson and Secretary Baker,
as well as Dr. Osler, will probably
be present to deliver speeches in
honor and memory of those Black
and Blue men who made the suA memorial
preme sacrifice.
bronze tablet ' containing the
names of 21 Hopkins men who
died in service in the Great War
will be placed temporarily in Gilman Hall until the memorial
building is erected. '
It has been positively settled
that there will be a lacrosse game
between the University of Toronto
and Johns Hopkins University in
the afternoon. Class and department dinners will cap the climax
of the historical reunion, which
will come to an end Saturday
night.
The interval between Saturday
and the Tuesday commencement
will contain a number of very interesting features, in which the
Maryland Historical Society, the
Liberty Loan Committee and other
organizations will participate.
The details will be announced
later.
' The periods between the main
events of the reunion will be interspersed with an equally entertaining series of secondary events.
The inspection of Homewood is in
charge of a committee consisting
of Dr. Barnett, chairman, Dean
Lantane, Dr. Matthews and Dr.
Whitehead. There will be induct
ed an exhibition of the architectural plans of the buildings which
will be erected as soon as funds
are available. To many alumni,
and even to many undergraduates
who have been here some time, a
trip through the maze of tunnels

The 'Varsity lacrosse team
closed an exceptionally successful
season last Saturday, when it defeated the Crescent Athletic Club
at Brooklyn, 4 to 1. According
to "Bill" Schmeisser, it is the first
time that we have beaten the
Crescents for 18 years. Yes, it's
true, for "Bill" knows, and since
1901 we have been unable to lower
their colors. In that year, the
Hopkins team, led by Captain J.
Edward Tyler, defeated that allstar combination of Brooklyn, 3
to 1, in a steady downpour of
rain, even though we lost the
league championship to Swarthmore. In that memorable game
our team was composed of famous
stickwielders such as Captain Tyler, "Doc" Abercrombie, "Father
Bill' himself, Harry Straus,
Hatch, Putts and the Bernheim
brothers.
But history is being made now,
and 18 years from today we will
talk of the famous team of 1919,
who beat the Crescents on their
own ground, with all their older
stars in the game.
The showing of the Black and
Blue on Saturday was especially
gratifying, since the team was
forced to Make the trip without
the services of Sutton, Morley,
Silberstein and Stuart, all of
whom were on the hospital list.
Thus the attack especially was
severely handicapped, but the combination which Assistant Coach
"Al" Voshell put on the field
proved very effective.
With the first few minutes of
play, the Crescents swept the 'Varsity off its feet and played the
ball about the Hopkins goal for
several minutes. The team then
steadied down and forced the play
into the home team's territory.
Defandorf and Allen scored in
quick succession; and the half ended 2 to 0 in Hopkins' favor. The
playing of the 'Varsity defense
was wonderful and Daugherty had
only a few oportunities, which he
easily handled.
In the second half, Hopkins
again got busy and Brennan
counted the third goal. The ball
seesawed up and down the field
with no score until O'Rourke tallied with a long shot for Crescent's only score. Baxley caught
one in near the crease and brought
the final score to 4-1.
The game was rather slow, but
there was a lot of good lacrosse
on both sides. The playing of

After the St. John's game last
Saturday, Harry Bloomsburg, our
snappy little shortstop, was elected to captain the team through
the season of 1920. Bloomsburg
has held down the shortstop position for the last three years, his
teamwork in collaboration with
Littman around the keystone sack
has been the star feature of the
defense _of the team.
As the St. John's game was
called on account of rain, the batting and fielding averages stand
as before. This means that Wallace wins with 8_ times at bat and
4 hits. The hitting ability of the
team is well shown by the fact
that 8 men are hitting above .300,
an exceptional feat on any ball
team. The fielding, however, is
below par; Judefind, Egerton and
Benson being the only fielders in
the .900 column. The team has
scored a total of 72 runs against
the 73 of its opponents during the
entire season.
St. John's has scheduled a postseason game to be played during
Alumni Week, so the relative
worth of the two teams may yet
be determined.

Two new Southern Intercollegiate records were established at
Homewood in the dual meet between Hopkins and Lafayette,
which the latter won,62/
2to 491/
1
2.
The feature event of the afternoon, the half-mile run, which
brought together Beverly Smith,
the Black and Blue star, and
Kleinspehn, the collegiate titleholder for this distance, was
marred by the disqualification of
Crawford, of Lafayette, who had
not figured strongly, but crossed
the finish line in front.
As the runners came down the
home-stretch Crawford unintentionally dowded the Hopkins runner off the track and was disqualified. The Hopkins officials, and
Smith himself, declined to accept
the judges' verdict, and Crawford's victory was allowed to
stand. Smith got second honors
and Kleinspehn finished third.
The new records were established in the mile run and in the
hammer throw. Crawford, who
won the 880, accomplished the
mile in 4 minutes and 22 seconds,
bettering the mark made by Frederick C. Lee, of Hopkins, by more
than 8 seconds. Leadbetter bettered his own record in the hammer throw by hurling it for a distance of more than 142 feet. His
old mark was 136 feet.
The 100-yard dash went to Kunkle, who was not really pressed,
although Van Ness finished a good
second. In the 120-yard high hurdles, first place went to Lafayette, but Wood drew up at the end
and the finish was very close.
Hopkins landed both places in
the 440, Smith finishing first and
Driver second. At no time was
Lafayette dangerous.
The two-mile run was one of the
most interesting races of the afternoon. Kemper had the pole
position and assumed the lead
on the outset. On the third
lap Graves moved out in front
and led for several trips around.

:
-- Engineers Travel To Inspect
Practical Construction.

The senior civil engineering
trip will be conducted by Professors C. J. Tilden and J. H.
Gregory. C. H. Bosley, C. E.
Keefer, C. W. Schmidt, A. W.
Taylor and J. K. Vickers, the
same seniors who took the trip
to Norfolk in April left for Albany last Saturday on an inspection trip which will last frgm
May 24 to May 29, inclusive and
will also include a study of engineering structure in and about
New York City.
According to the outline of the
plans of the trip, on Sunday the
Hopkins men will meet Assistant Engineer R. S. Greenman, of
the eastern division, state engineer's office, and go with him to
the canal locks at Waterford, to
the dam on the Mohawk river
and to other places if time permits.
On Monday Professor
Gregory in the company of Mr.
'Wallace Granalch, commissioner
of public works, will take the
seniors to the Albany sewerage
and filtration works.
The Hopkins party will take
the eight o'clock night boat to
New York. The moonlight trip
down the Hudson from Albany to
New York Will be a treat to them
and will add to the interest of
the journey. Mr. F. F. Moore,
designing engineer of the New
York Board of Water Supply,

will conduct Dr. Gregory and his
men to the Kensico dam and aerator at Valhalla on Tuesday
morning. The Dyckman street
sewage screens will then be studied by the party under the supervision of Mr. C. E. Gregory, engineer, sewage disposal, New
York. In the afternoon the seniors will meet Professor Tilden
and go to Brooklyn bridge. In
the evening the party will have
dinner at the Harvard Club with
Mr. Clifford Holland, tunnel engineer for the public service commission, as their guest.
On Wednesday, May 28, Professor Tilden and the five students will spend the day in the
study of the East River tunnels
under the direction of Mr. Holland.
On Thursday, the last day of
the trip, Dr. Tilden and his party
will meet Mr. J. A. Drodge at the
Grand Central terminal. He will
secure passes for the Hell Gate
bridge. The New York, New
Haven and Hartford Railroad
Company will furnish a guide.
They will also inspect the Williamsburg bridge, after which
they will return to Baltimore.
Judging from the plan of the
trip and the length of it, the
senior engineers will return with
an account of a trip that will
have proved more exciting and
interesting than the one they
made at Norfolk.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

MAY 27, 1919

See The Activities of Hopkins Grow.

THE NEWS - LETTER wonders if
the students of Johns Hopkins realize what the University has acquired in its baby activity, the
newly organized orchestra. This
is the first time that a University
orchestra has been organized here
for the study of serious music, and
its first concert in McCoy Hall
gave every indication that the
adventure would be successful.
Every new undertaking enegetically and successfully prosecuted
means new fame, new glory and
more college life for Hopkins. We
congratulate most heartily Mr.
Edwin Litchfield Turnbull, the
president of the association,
t, through whose unttring efforts
Bopkins is to be placed, musically,
we hope, on as high a plane as she
(occupies in many other'fields, Mr.
Charles H. Bochau, its able conductor, and the members of the
orchestra.
We hope that the undergraduates of the University will not
neglect the wonderful opportunity
of improving their musical talent,
and of engaging in a college activity with graduate students and
older friends of Hopkins. We believe that the college is ready now
for great expansion in every direction. Don't -bewail the imagined
lack of college life, but rather
support every activity which is as
worthy as this one.

Athletic Comparisons.

We now have no reason to be
ashamed of, or to make apologies
for, the athletics of Johns Hopkins. On the other hand, as the
college year draws to a close,
every member of the University
should look with pride upon the
achievements of her representatives.
A comparison between the track
meet held at Homewood last Saturday, Hopkins vs. Lafayette, and
the meet between Princeton and
Harvard, held on the same day,
At Homewood
is interesting.
better times were made in the
220-yard dash and in the mile run;
more distance was made in the
hammer throw, discus throw and
high jump, than at the other meet.
On the other hand, the times Of the
Harvard-Princeton meet in the two
mile and hurdles exceeded those
made here, and they were also better in the broad jump ancl pole
vault events. Times registered for
both meets in the 100-yard dash,
440-yard run and 881iyard run
were identical.
It is gratifying to think that
the Hopkins track team, though
she started the year under unfavorable conditions, and with no
very bright outlook, has escaped
that promised destiny, and by
dint of enthusiastic work has entered a class with some of the
largest universities in the country.
We hope that the new captain,
John R. Bartels, upon whose election we congratulate the team,
will endeavor to enlarge the squad
and so provide Hopkins with runners who will win "seconds" and
"thirds," as well as "firsts."
Our lacrosse victory over the
Crescent Athletic Club should not
and does not go unnoticed. It was
a brilliant culmination to a highly.
successful season, and it speaks
well indeed not only for the players, but also for the coaching staff.
This year has given Hopkins a
strong athletic "boost," and with
Mr. Murphy.installed as director,
we feel sure that it is only the beginning of a long series of successful seasons.
Pennsylvania and Delaware Beat
Hopkins Racqueters.

The tennis team made its final
bow last Saturday, when it was
taken into camp by the Delaware
College racqueters by a score of
6-0. Handicapped by the absence
of Stuart Symington, the Black
and Blue fought hard till the last
point and forced Delaware to
deuce sets in every match.
The most interesting match of
the day was when .Humphrey, of
Delaware, defeated "Phil" Craft,
9-7, 4-6, 86. This match brought
together two players of the same
style, and at the end of four hands
of play the fates decided in favor
of Delaware.
Hopkins tennis team suffered
another defeat on the courts at
the hands of the University of

PRIZE SPEAKING CONTESTS HELD
Driver Wins Tocqueville Medal—Adams
Medal Goes to Heiner—France and
League of Nations Subject of
Tocqueville Contest.

On Friday evening, May 24,
1919, both the Adams contest and
the Tocqueville contest in public
speaking were held in the Civil
Engineering Hall. R. Graham
Heiner won the Adams contest
and Warren M. Driver was victorious in the contest for the Tocqueville medal.
In the Adams contest, named in
memory of Herbert Baxter Adams, each of the participants gave
a memorized selection from some
contemporary speech. The speakers and their selections were:
George Goetz — "Permanent
Peace," Wilson.
It. Graham Heiner—"The Challenge and the Conflict," Lloyd
George. •
Morris H. Goodman — "War
With Germany," Wilson.
The judges, Dr. A. Cohen Dr.
Henry Slonimsky and Mr.'
Lawrence II. Baker, were somewhat
put to it in judging the best
speaker. On the first ballot, indeed, each of time three contestants
received one of the three votes.
After careful consideration, however, the judges agreed that Heiner was undoubtedly the best.
After the Adams contest was
over the Tocqueville contest began.
Dr. French, the presiding officer,
explained that but five Tocqueville medals were awarded each
year in the United States: Hopkins, Harvard, Princeton and Tulane each get one, and in California, Leland-Stanford and the
University of California compete
for the fifth.
The speeches are more in the
nature of a lecture than an argument, and are original. They
must have France as their general topic. This year the general
subject was "The Relation of
France to a League of Nations."
"France and the League" was
the first speaker's—Raphael Levy
—subject. He argued that France
could not afford to refuse to join
the League of Nations.
The next speaker, and, as it ultimately turned out, the winner,
He
was Warren M. Driver.
showed what her allies owe to
France and the reasons they are
so much indebted to the republic.
Driver's address was not only well
delivered, but the subject matter
was well and forcibly presented.
Hsin-Hai Chang, the next speaker, made an exceedingly good address. His subject was "France
and the Balance of power." His
point of view was that France
could not go on without accepting
the League, otherwise Germany
and Russia,• he thinks, would
probably unite to crush France
at some future date.
"France Without a League of
Nations" was Richard T. Cox's
topic. He concluded that France

Dr. R. A. Stewart and Dr. Aaron

A Patriotic Investment.

To the Editorial Staff of the XewsLetter and Students of the Hopkins University, Baltimore City:
Young Gentlemen — Being a
Frenchman by birth, but "American by heart, soul and body," I
take the liberty to send you these
few lines:
I have been working for years
after an invention of mine own,
who will give to U. S. of A.: The
fastest boat and the fastest dirigible of the world. "We must be
supreme on seas and in the air."
I have built 24 machines, small
model, and, having reached my
goal, I am ready to build my No.
25, if you are willing to co-operate with me. As I am a man who
firmly believes in reciprocity, having been brought up that way, I
come to you, asking you if you are
willing to help me. I am going
to build a bigger machine who will
have more power — faster speed.
Are you with me? Only $60 will
complete and finish it in good
shape, and as I expect to sell it
to our Government for a good
price, you will get your share.
My proposition to you, young
'gentlemen, is true, honest and sincere, and even with my 75 years
I am able yet to be useful to my
adopted country.
Respectfully and sincerely yours,
A. LE CANZ, Machinist, .
118 E. Franklin St.
Baltimore, May 25, 1919.

Dr. Erasmo Buceta, associate in
Spanish at this University, will
not return next year. He will
teach at the University of California.
Dr. Maria de Maezta, president
of the International Institute for
Girls at Madrid. a brilliant lecturer and essayist, delivered a lecture on "The Contemporary Spanish Novel" in the Romance Language Seminary on Friday, May
9. She made a comprehensive survey of the literary tendencies beginning with the last representative of the realistic school.
At a meeting of the Southern
Society for Philosophy and Psychology, held at Nashville, Tenn.,
May 9 and 10, Prof. Knight Dunlap was elected president of the
society.
The annual exhibit of the Affordby Kindergarten-Primary Normal School and the Alumnae Association was held in Donovan
Room, Oilman Hall, May 22. The
work of the students, of the Alumnae and of the children of several
kindergartens was displayed. Lantern slides of the children at work
were also shown. The punch and
cakes were served by five beautiful
young girls. The Prince of Peace
and the Garrison kindergarten
classes took part in games on the
campus.
Professor David 31. Robinson
was elected president of the College Art Association of America
at its eighth annual meeting held
at the Metropolitan Museum of
Art, New York City, May 12-14.
Dr. Carl C. Thomas will resume work here next October as
head and professor of the mechan- •
ical engineering department. He
has been on a leave of absence
for the last two years and is at
present manager of the machinery
department with the American
International Shipbuilding Corporation, Hog. Island, Pa.
James B. Arthur, acting associate professor of electrical engineering, will take Dr. Kowenhoven's place during the latter's
absence. He was formerly at the
U. S. Naval Academy.

The Johns Hopkins memorial
reunion, the greatest and most appropriate one of its kind that has
ever been attempted at this University, will be chock full of interesting features, the details of
which were worked out at the last
weekly meeting of the general
committee.
The reunion will be formally
opened on Thursday, June 19,
which will be the day for the reception of the alumni. The senior
dance will probably be held on
that night.
On Friday, a baseball game will
be played between the Johns Hopkins team and a visiting team,
most likely that of St. John's.
The memorial exercises will be
held on Saturday. Prominent
Hopkins alumni, such as President Wilson and Secretary Baker,
as well as Dr. Osler, will probably
be present to deliver speeches in
honor and memory of those Black
and Blue men who made the suA memorial
preme sacrifice.
bronze tablet ' containing the
names of 21 Hopkins men who
died in service in the Great War
will be placed temporarily in Gilman Hall until the memorial
building is erected. '
It has been positively settled
that there will be a lacrosse game
between the University of Toronto
and Johns Hopkins University in
the afternoon. Class and department dinners will cap the climax
of the historical reunion, which
will come to an end Saturday
night.
The interval between Saturday
and the Tuesday commencement
will contain a number of very interesting features, in which the
Maryland Historical Society, the
Liberty Loan Committee and other
organizations will participate.
The details will be announced
later.
' The periods between the main
events of the reunion will be interspersed with an equally entertaining series of secondary events.
The inspection of Homewood is in
charge of a committee consisting
of Dr. Barnett, chairman, Dean
Lantane, Dr. Matthews and Dr.
Whitehead. There will be induct
ed an exhibition of the architectural plans of the buildings which
will be erected as soon as funds
are available. To many alumni,
and even to many undergraduates
who have been here some time, a
trip through the maze of tunnels

The 'Varsity lacrosse team
closed an exceptionally successful
season last Saturday, when it defeated the Crescent Athletic Club
at Brooklyn, 4 to 1. According
to "Bill" Schmeisser, it is the first
time that we have beaten the
Crescents for 18 years. Yes, it's
true, for "Bill" knows, and since
1901 we have been unable to lower
their colors. In that year, the
Hopkins team, led by Captain J.
Edward Tyler, defeated that allstar combination of Brooklyn, 3
to 1, in a steady downpour of
rain, even though we lost the
league championship to Swarthmore. In that memorable game
our team was composed of famous
stickwielders such as Captain Tyler, "Doc" Abercrombie, "Father
Bill' himself, Harry Straus,
Hatch, Putts and the Bernheim
brothers.
But history is being made now,
and 18 years from today we will
talk of the famous team of 1919,
who beat the Crescents on their
own ground, with all their older
stars in the game.
The showing of the Black and
Blue on Saturday was especially
gratifying, since the team was
forced to Make the trip without
the services of Sutton, Morley,
Silberstein and Stuart, all of
whom were on the hospital list.
Thus the attack especially was
severely handicapped, but the combination which Assistant Coach
"Al" Voshell put on the field
proved very effective.
With the first few minutes of
play, the Crescents swept the 'Varsity off its feet and played the
ball about the Hopkins goal for
several minutes. The team then
steadied down and forced the play
into the home team's territory.
Defandorf and Allen scored in
quick succession; and the half ended 2 to 0 in Hopkins' favor. The
playing of the 'Varsity defense
was wonderful and Daugherty had
only a few oportunities, which he
easily handled.
In the second half, Hopkins
again got busy and Brennan
counted the third goal. The ball
seesawed up and down the field
with no score until O'Rourke tallied with a long shot for Crescent's only score. Baxley caught
one in near the crease and brought
the final score to 4-1.
The game was rather slow, but
there was a lot of good lacrosse
on both sides. The playing of

After the St. John's game last
Saturday, Harry Bloomsburg, our
snappy little shortstop, was elected to captain the team through
the season of 1920. Bloomsburg
has held down the shortstop position for the last three years, his
teamwork in collaboration with
Littman around the keystone sack
has been the star feature of the
defense _of the team.
As the St. John's game was
called on account of rain, the batting and fielding averages stand
as before. This means that Wallace wins with 8_ times at bat and
4 hits. The hitting ability of the
team is well shown by the fact
that 8 men are hitting above .300,
an exceptional feat on any ball
team. The fielding, however, is
below par; Judefind, Egerton and
Benson being the only fielders in
the .900 column. The team has
scored a total of 72 runs against
the 73 of its opponents during the
entire season.
St. John's has scheduled a postseason game to be played during
Alumni Week, so the relative
worth of the two teams may yet
be determined.

Two new Southern Intercollegiate records were established at
Homewood in the dual meet between Hopkins and Lafayette,
which the latter won,62/
2to 491/
1
2.
The feature event of the afternoon, the half-mile run, which
brought together Beverly Smith,
the Black and Blue star, and
Kleinspehn, the collegiate titleholder for this distance, was
marred by the disqualification of
Crawford, of Lafayette, who had
not figured strongly, but crossed
the finish line in front.
As the runners came down the
home-stretch Crawford unintentionally dowded the Hopkins runner off the track and was disqualified. The Hopkins officials, and
Smith himself, declined to accept
the judges' verdict, and Crawford's victory was allowed to
stand. Smith got second honors
and Kleinspehn finished third.
The new records were established in the mile run and in the
hammer throw. Crawford, who
won the 880, accomplished the
mile in 4 minutes and 22 seconds,
bettering the mark made by Frederick C. Lee, of Hopkins, by more
than 8 seconds. Leadbetter bettered his own record in the hammer throw by hurling it for a distance of more than 142 feet. His
old mark was 136 feet.
The 100-yard dash went to Kunkle, who was not really pressed,
although Van Ness finished a good
second. In the 120-yard high hurdles, first place went to Lafayette, but Wood drew up at the end
and the finish was very close.
Hopkins landed both places in
the 440, Smith finishing first and
Driver second. At no time was
Lafayette dangerous.
The two-mile run was one of the
most interesting races of the afternoon. Kemper had the pole
position and assumed the lead
on the outset. On the third
lap Graves moved out in front
and led for several trips around.

-- Engineers Travel To Inspect

The senior civil engineering
trip will be conducted by Professors C. J. Tilden and J. H.
Gregory. C. H. Bosley, C. E.
Keefer, C. W. Schmidt, A. W.
Taylor and J. K. Vickers, the
same seniors who took the trip
to Norfolk in April left for Albany last Saturday on an inspection trip which will last frgm
May 24 to May 29, inclusive and
will also include a study of engineering structure in and about
New York City.
According to the outline of the
plans of the trip, on Sunday the
Hopkins men will meet Assistant Engineer R. S. Greenman, of
the eastern division, state engineer's office, and go with him to
the canal locks at Waterford, to
the dam on the Mohawk river
and to other places if time permits.
On Monday Professor
Gregory in the company of Mr.
'Wallace Granalch, commissioner
of public works, will take the
seniors to the Albany sewerage
and filtration works.
The Hopkins party will take
the eight o'clock night boat to
New York. The moonlight trip
down the Hudson from Albany to
New York Will be a treat to them
and will add to the interest of
the journey. Mr. F. F. Moore,
designing engineer of the New
York Board of Water Supply,

will conduct Dr. Gregory and his
men to the Kensico dam and aerator at Valhalla on Tuesday
morning. The Dyckman street
sewage screens will then be studied by the party under the supervision of Mr. C. E. Gregory, engineer, sewage disposal, New
York. In the afternoon the seniors will meet Professor Tilden
and go to Brooklyn bridge. In
the evening the party will have
dinner at the Harvard Club with
Mr. Clifford Holland, tunnel engineer for the public service commission, as their guest.
On Wednesday, May 28, Professor Tilden and the five students will spend the day in the
study of the East River tunnels
under the direction of Mr. Holland.
On Thursday, the last day of
the trip, Dr. Tilden and his party
will meet Mr. J. A. Drodge at the
Grand Central terminal. He will
secure passes for the Hell Gate
bridge. The New York, New
Haven and Hartford Railroad
Company will furnish a guide.
They will also inspect the Williamsburg bridge, after which
they will return to Baltimore.
Judging from the plan of the
trip and the length of it, the
senior engineers will return with
an account of a trip that will
have proved more exciting and
interesting than the one they
made at Norfolk.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

MAY 27, 1919

See The Activities of Hopkins Grow.

THE NEWS - LETTER wonders if
the students of Johns Hopkins realize what the University has acquired in its baby activity, the
newly organized orchestra. This
is the first time that a University
orchestra has been organized here
for the study of serious music, and
its first concert in McCoy Hall
gave every indication that the
adventure would be successful.
Every new undertaking enegetically and successfully prosecuted
means new fame, new glory and
more college life for Hopkins. We
congratulate most heartily Mr.
Edwin Litchfield Turnbull, the
president of the association,
t, through whose unttring efforts
Bopkins is to be placed, musically,
we hope, on as high a plane as she
(occupies in many other'fields, Mr.
Charles H. Bochau, its able conductor, and the members of the
orchestra.
We hope that the undergraduates of the University will not
neglect the wonderful opportunity
of improving their musical talent,
and of engaging in a college activity with graduate students and
older friends of Hopkins. We believe that the college is ready now
for great expansion in every direction. Don't -bewail the imagined
lack of college life, but rather
support every activity which is as
worthy as this one.

Athletic Comparisons.

We now have no reason to be
ashamed of, or to make apologies
for, the athletics of Johns Hopkins. On the other hand, as the
college year draws to a close,
every member of the University
should look with pride upon the
achievements of her representatives.
A comparison between the track
meet held at Homewood last Saturday, Hopkins vs. Lafayette, and
the meet between Princeton and
Harvard, held on the same day,
At Homewood
is interesting.
better times were made in the
220-yard dash and in the mile run;
more distance was made in the
hammer throw, discus throw and
high jump, than at the other meet.
On the other hand, the times Of the
Harvard-Princeton meet in the two
mile and hurdles exceeded those
made here, and they were also better in the broad jump ancl pole
vault events. Times registered for
both meets in the 100-yard dash,
440-yard run and 881iyard run
were identical.
It is gratifying to think that
the Hopkins track team, though
she started the year under unfavorable conditions, and with no
very bright outlook, has escaped
that promised destiny, and by
dint of enthusiastic work has entered a class with some of the
largest universities in the country.
We hope that the new captain,
John R. Bartels, upon whose election we congratulate the team,
will endeavor to enlarge the squad
and so provide Hopkins with runners who will win "seconds" and
"thirds," as well as "firsts."
Our lacrosse victory over the
Crescent Athletic Club should not
and does not go unnoticed. It was
a brilliant culmination to a highly.
successful season, and it speaks
well indeed not only for the players, but also for the coaching staff.
This year has given Hopkins a
strong athletic "boost," and with
Mr. Murphy.installed as director,
we feel sure that it is only the beginning of a long series of successful seasons.

together two players of the same
style, and at the end of four hands
of play the fates decided in favor
of Delaware.

PRIZE SPEAKING CONTESTS HELD
Driver Wins Tocqueville Medal—Adams
Medal Goes to Heiner—France and
League of Nations Subject of
Tocqueville Contest.

On Friday evening, May 24,
1919, both the Adams contest and
the Tocqueville contest in public
speaking were held in the Civil
Engineering Hall. R. Graham
Heiner won the Adams contest
and Warren M. Driver was victorious in the contest for the Tocqueville medal.
In the Adams contest, named in
memory of Herbert Baxter Adams, each of the participants gave
a memorized selection from some
contemporary speech. The speakers and their selections were:
George Goetz — "Permanent
Peace," Wilson.
It. Graham Heiner—"The Challenge and the Conflict," Lloyd
George. •
Morris H. Goodman — "War
With Germany," Wilson.
The judges, Dr. A. Cohen Dr.
Henry Slonimsky and Mr.'
Lawrence II. Baker, were somewhat
put to it in judging the best
speaker. On the first ballot, indeed, each of time three contestants
received one of the three votes.
After careful consideration, however, the judges agreed that Heiner was undoubtedly the best.
After the Adams contest was
over the Tocqueville contest began.
Dr. French, the presiding officer,
explained that but five Tocqueville medals were awarded each
year in the United States: Hopkins, Harvard, Princeton and Tulane each get one, and in California, Leland-Stanford and the
University of California compete
for the fifth.
The speeches are more in the
nature of a lecture than an argument, and are original. They
must have France as their general topic. This year the general
subject was "The Relation of
France to a League of Nations."
"France and the League" was
the first speaker's—Raphael Levy
—subject. He argued that France
could not afford to refuse to join
the League of Nations.
The next speaker, and, as it ultimately turned out, the winner,
He
was Warren M. Driver.
showed what her allies owe to
France and the reasons they are
so much indebted to the republic.
Driver's address was not only well
delivered, but the subject matter
was well and forcibly presented.
Hsin-Hai Chang, the next speaker, made an exceedingly good address. His subject was "France
and the Balance of power." His
point of view was that France
could not go on without accepting
the League, otherwise Germany
and Russia,• he thinks, would
probably unite to crush France
at some future date.
"France Without a League of
Nations" was Richard T. Cox's
topic. He concluded that France

would be helpless without the

The judges of the Tocqueville
contest were Dr. John M. Vincent,
Dr. R. A. Stewart and Dr. Aaron
Selmaffer.
A Patriotic Investment.

To the Editorial Staff of the XewsLetter and Students of the Hopkins University, Baltimore City:
Young Gentlemen — Being a
Frenchman by birth, but "American by heart, soul and body," I
take the liberty to send you these
few lines:
I have been working for years
after an invention of mine own,
who will give to U. S. of A.: The
fastest boat and the fastest dirigible of the world. "We must be
supreme on seas and in the air."
I have built 24 machines, small
model, and, having reached my
goal, I am ready to build my No.
25, if you are willing to co-operate with me. As I am a man who
firmly believes in reciprocity, having been brought up that way, I
come to you, asking you if you are
willing to help me. I am going
to build a bigger machine who will
have more power — faster speed.
Are you with me? Only $60 will
complete and finish it in good
shape, and as I expect to sell it
to our Government for a good
price, you will get your share.
My proposition to you, young
'gentlemen, is true, honest and sincere, and even with my 75 years
I am able yet to be useful to my
adopted country.
Respectfully and sincerely yours,
A. LE CANZ, Machinist, .
118 E. Franklin St.
Baltimore, May 25, 1919.

Dr. Erasmo Buceta, associate in
Spanish at this University, will
not return next year. He will
teach at the University of California.
Dr. Maria de Maezta, president
of the International Institute for
Girls at Madrid. a brilliant lecturer and essayist, delivered a lecture on "The Contemporary Spanish Novel" in the Romance Language Seminary on Friday, May
9. She made a comprehensive survey of the literary tendencies beginning with the last representative of the realistic school.
At a meeting of the Southern
Society for Philosophy and Psychology, held at Nashville, Tenn.,
May 9 and 10, Prof. Knight Dunlap was elected president of the
society.
The annual exhibit of the Affordby Kindergarten-Primary Normal School and the Alumnae Association was held in Donovan
Room, Oilman Hall, May 22. The
work of the students, of the Alumnae and of the children of several
kindergartens was displayed. Lantern slides of the children at work
were also shown. The punch and
cakes were served by five beautiful
young girls. The Prince of Peace
and the Garrison kindergarten
classes took part in games on the
campus.
Professor David 31. Robinson
was elected president of the College Art Association of America
at its eighth annual meeting held
at the Metropolitan Museum of
Art, New York City, May 12-14.
Dr. Carl C. Thomas will resume work here next October as
head and professor of the mechan- •
ical engineering department. He
has been on a leave of absence
for the last two years and is at
present manager of the machinery
department with the American
International Shipbuilding Corporation, Hog. Island, Pa.
James B. Arthur, acting associate professor of electrical engineering, will take Dr. Kowenhoven's place during the latter's
absence. He was formerly at the
U. S. Naval Academy.
